newsitem.title: USA: US Treasuries boosted by technical buying at noon.
newsitem.headline: US Treasuries boosted by technical buying at noon.

text.p: U.S. Treasury prices were mostly higher at midday, gaining ground as dealers and commercial buyers jumped on the back of a late-morning surge in the June bond contract, analysts said.

"It's hard to tell whether it's just somebody getting long here or covering shorts. (It is) very technical in that 108-30 went and that triggered some stops," said Josh Stiles, a senior bond analyst at I.D.E.A. Inc.
But Treasuries languished for most of the morning after an early lift on the back of data on durable goods orders faded, traders said.

"There has been some buying off the low but with the data coming out somewhat stronger than expected, there is a little bit of concern the slowdown people were looking for may not materialize," said one trader at a primary dealer.
But, the dealer added, it is a little too early to cast a vote either way with respect to the future rate of growth.
Short-covering after the numbers boosted the back end, flattening the curve in the coupon sector, analysts said.
The 30-year bond was up 10/32 around midday, trading at 95-9/32. The yield eased back to 7.00 percent, from 7.04 percent earlier.
The 10-year was also lifted 4/32, with market experts citing strong support from Middle East players. At noon the 10-year stood at 98-30/32, yielding 6.77 percent.
"The Middle East accounts were on a mission, they have a certain program and when the 10-year note sector gets to certain levels they buy it," said Roseanne Briggen, a bond analyst at MCM MoneyWatch.
On Wednesday, the Commerce Department reported that durables rose 1.4 percent in April and March orders were revised upwards to show a 2.2 percent decline, from a 2.6 percent fall originally.

The number was a tad stronger than the 1.3 percent which had been forecast. But analysts noted the data was not uniformly strong, citing a 4.5-percent rise in transportation equipment and a 28-percent surge in defense capital orders.

"This report is peppered with all kinds of conflicting signs," said David Resler, chief economist at Nomura Securities International Inc. "On the one hand, there is fairly discouraging news on the non-defense capital goods side, but the overall picture of orders looks pretty good.
The data certainly does not indicate the economy is growing out of control, he added.
Meanwhile, the two-year note was struggling just to tread water ahead of the Treasury's $16.5 billion auction on Wednesday.
The two-year was flat at 100-05/32, yielding 6.28 percent.
"There is no arbitrage bid for the two year note that I'm aware of, because neither twos nor fives have gotten hot in retail recently," Briggen said.
The Treasury is scheduled to sell $12 billion of new five-year paper on Thursday.
The Federal Reserve refrained from open market operations on Wednesday.
The five-year note was up 2/32, also garnering support from talk of Middle East interest and rumored central bank demand. Around midday, it stood at 100-1/32, with a yield of 6.62 percent.
The bill market was firm, with the three-month and six-month each down three basis points, at 5.01 percent and 5.23 percent respectively.
((--Alden Bentley, 212 859 1667))
